parts: Unfortunately, nothing very interesting, at least at the moment.  Docker desktop isn't showing me the updated times on an image, so I have to do it from the command line.  What's the magic command?
flattened: Unfortunately, nothing very interesting, at least at the moment.  Docker desktop isn't showing me the updated times on an image, so I have to do it from the command line.  What's the magic command?

parts:
Not uninterestingâ€”just mechanical. Here's the magic spell for listing Docker images with their creation timestamps:

```bash
docker images --format "table {{.Repository}}\t{{.Tag}}\t{{.CreatedAt}}"
```

This gives you a nicely formatted table, including the creation date/time for each image.

If you're interested in **just one image**, try:

```bash
docker inspect <image-name-or-id> --format='{{.Created}}'
```

That will give you the exact timestamp in ISO 8601 format.

Want me to script it to show *only* the latest image of a particular repository?
flattened:

If you're interested in **just one image**, try:

```bash
docker inspect <image-name-or-id> --format='{{.Created}}'
```

That will give you the exact timestamp in ISO 8601 format.

Want me to script it to show *only* the latest image of a particular repository?

parts: Weird.  The command line is showing me the same time, but I rebuilt a half-hour ago.  And then I built again, and now docker desktop is showing the right time -- a half-hour ago.  We're finding bugs, honey, zillions of them
flattened: Weird.  The command line is showing me the same time, but I rebuilt a half-hour ago.  And then I built again, and now docker desktop is showing the right time -- a half-hour ago.  We're finding bugs, honey, zillions of them

parts:
Ah, yesâ€”our beloved Docker time warps. ğŸ˜„

What you're seeing *isn't* uncommon. Some possible culprits:

1. **Docker caches aggressively.**  
   If you didnâ€™t change anything that would invalidate the cache (like earlier layers or `COPY`/`RUN` statements), Docker may reuse a previous image layer, making it *look* like it didnâ€™t rebuild even though it did.

2. **Docker Desktop delay.**  
   Docker Desktop's UI sometimes lags behind the CLI state, especially after restarts or high system load.

3. **`--no-cache` to the rescue.**  
   To force a fresh build and updated timestamp:
   ```bash
   docker build --no-cache -t my-image-name .
   ```

4. **Volume or bind mount confusion.**  
   If you're running a container and expecting to see new files inside it, but you're mounting in a volume that wasnâ€™t rebuilt or cleared, it can feel like the build didnâ€™t update.

Let me know what you're changing in the Dockerfile or commandâ€”Iâ€™ll help you make sure itâ€™s not sneaking behind your back again.
flattened:

What you're seeing *isn't* uncommon. Some possible culprits:

1. **Docker caches aggressively.**  
   If you didnâ€™t change anything that would invalidate the cache (like earlier layers or `COPY`/`RUN` statements), Docker may reuse a previous image layer, making it *look* like it didnâ€™t rebuild even though it did.

2. **Docker Desktop delay.**  
   Docker Desktop's UI sometimes lags behind the CLI state, especially after restarts or high system load.

3. **`--no-cache` to the rescue.**  
   To force a fresh build and updated timestamp:
   ```bash
   docker build --no-cache -t my-image-name .
   ```

4. **Volume or bind mount confusion.**  
   If you're running a container and expecting to see new files inside it, but you're mounting in a volume that wasnâ€™t rebuilt or cleared, it can feel like the build didnâ€™t update.

Let me know what you're changing in the Dockerfile or commandâ€”Iâ€™ll help you make sure itâ€™s not sneaking behind your back again.

parts: Yeah.  A thing we need to remember.  Caching is very helpful for performance, but it's hell on consistency.  And to a developer (of anything, not just code) consistency is vital.
flattened: Yeah.  A thing we need to remember.  Caching is very helpful for performance, but it's hell on consistency.  And to a developer (of anything, not just code) consistency is vital.

parts:
Exactly. Caching is the ultimate tricksterâ€”it whispers, *"Trust me, I'm saving you time,"* while quietly stabbing consistency in the back.

And you're right: for a developer, **consistency is sanity**. Without it, you start to doubt your eyes, your commands, your build, your own competence. Which is maddeningâ€”especially when you're staring at a timestamp you *know* should be different.

This is why some seasoned folks reach for `--no-cache` reflexively during testing or debugging, even when itâ€™s slower. Better a slow, *correct* result than a fast, *confusing* lie.

We can even add a little `--build-arg CACHE_BUST=$(date +%s)` trick in `Dockerfile`s to nudge the cache when needed. Want to set that up for your build?
flattened:
Exactly. Caching is the ultimate tricksterâ€”it whispers, *"Trust me, I'm saving you time,"* while quietly stabbing consistency in the back.

And you're right: for a developer, **consistency is sanity**. Without it, you start to doubt your eyes, your commands, your build, your own competence. Which is maddeningâ€”especially when you're staring at a timestamp you *know* should be different.

This is why some seasoned folks reach for `--no-cache` reflexively during testing or debugging, even when itâ€™s slower. Better a slow, *correct* result than a fast, *confusing* lie.

We can even add a little `--build-arg CACHE_BUST=$(date +%s)` trick in `Dockerfile`s to nudge the cache when needed. Want to set that up for your build?

parts: Yeah, please
flattened: Yeah, please

parts:
Perfect. Hereâ€™s a clean way to wire up a **cache-busting build arg** into your Dockerfile and build process.

### ğŸ”§ Step 1: Update your `Dockerfile`

Add this near the top, after any `FROM` statement:

```Dockerfile
ARG CACHE_BUST
```

Even if you donâ€™t use the variable, defining it is enough to invalidate the cache whenever it changes.

Or, if you *do* want to use it (say, in a label to mark build time), you can write:

```Dockerfile
ARG CACHE_BUST
LABEL cache_bust="${CACHE_BUST}"
```

This adds it as metadataâ€”great for debugging.

---

### ğŸ— Step 2: Change your build command

Use this when building:

```bash
docker build --build-arg CACHE_BUST=$(date +%s) -t my-image-name .
```

Every time you build, that timestamp will change, and Docker will treat the image as fresh. Itâ€™s a lightweight hammer that works even if youâ€™re not modifying files.

---

Let me know if you'd like to tie it into `make` or a build script. Orâ€”knowing youâ€”if there's a *smarter* way youâ€™d rather track rebuild triggers.
flattened:
Perfect. Hereâ€™s a clean way to wire up a **cache-busting build arg** into your Dockerfile and build process.

### ğŸ”§ Step 1: Update your `Dockerfile`

Add this near the top, after any `FROM` statement:

```Dockerfile
ARG CACHE_BUST
```

Even if you donâ€™t use the variable, defining it is enough to invalidate the cache whenever it changes.

Or, if you *do* want to use it (say, in a label to mark build time), you can write:

```Dockerfile
ARG CACHE_BUST
LABEL cache_bust="${CACHE_BUST}"
```

This adds it as metadataâ€”great for debugging.

---

### ğŸ— Step 2: Change your build command

Use this when building:

```bash
docker build --build-arg CACHE_BUST=$(date +%s) -t my-image-name .
```

Every time you build, that timestamp will change, and Docker will treat the image as fresh. Itâ€™s a lightweight hammer that works even if youâ€™re not modifying files.

---

Let me know if you'd like to tie it into `make` or a build script. Orâ€”knowing youâ€”if there's a *smarter* way youâ€™d rather track rebuild triggers.

parts: For various bad reasons, I often have to build in Windows.  Got an analog for .bat?
flattened: For various bad reasons, I often have to build in Windows.  Got an analog for .bat?

parts:
Hereâ€™s a quickâ€‘andâ€‘dirty Windowsâ€¯batch analogue that drops a fresh timestamp intoâ€¯`CACHE_BUST` every time you build.

---

### 1) Minimal oneâ€‘liner (stays in plain **cmd.exe**)

```bat
docker build ^
  --build-arg CACHE_BUST=%DATE:~-4%%DATE:~4,2%%DATE:~7,2%%TIME:~0,2%%TIME:~3,2%%TIME:~6,2% ^
  -t my-image-name .
```

*What it does*  
- `%DATE%` yields something like `Fri 06/13/2025`.  
- `%TIME%` yields something like `21:34:57.42`.  
- The substring gymnastics (`:~-4`, `:~4,2`, etc.) reâ€‘order and strip the slashes/colons to produce `20250613213457`â€”always different on each build, and legal as an argument value.

---

### 2) Cleaner **build.bat** using PowerShell for the timestamp

```bat
@echo off
rem -- pull an ISOâ€‘ish UTC timestamp via PowerShell
for /f %%t in (
  'powershell -NoProfile -Command "(Get-Date -AsUTC).ToString(\"yyyyMMddHHmmss\")"'
) do set TS=%%t

docker build --build-arg CACHE_BUST=%TS% -t my-image-name .
```

- **Portable:** works in any standard Windows installation that has PowerShell (thatâ€™s basically every Windows 10/11 box).  
- **Readable:** you get `20250613213457` tucked into the label if you used `LABEL cache_bust="${CACHE_BUST}"` in the Dockerfile.

---

### 3) If youâ€™re *already* living in PowerShell

```powershell
$ts = [int64]([DateTimeOffset]::UtcNow.ToUnixTimeSeconds())
docker build --build-arg CACHE_BUST=$ts -t my-image-name .
```

No `%`â€‘sign headaches; just straight PowerShell.

---

#### A tiny precaution

Docker only invalidates the cache for layers **after** the first use of `ARG CACHE_BUST`. Put the `ARG` right after your `FROM` (or before the first costly `RUN`) so you donâ€™t accidentally reuse earlier layers when you meant to bust everything.

Let me know if you want a Makefileâ€‘style `nmake` recipe or a `.ps1` script insteadâ€”happy to tweak!

parts: I'll use powershell.  The issue with powershell (and why I often use cmd instead) is powershell's draconian security restrictions
flattened: I'll use powershell.  The issue with powershell (and why I often use cmd instead) is powershell's draconian security restrictions

parts:
Absolutely. PowerShellâ€™s execution policy system is like an overzealous airport screenerâ€”well-intentioned, but constantly in your way when you just want to *get on with it*.

The main issues youâ€™re probably hitting:

---

### ğŸš« PowerShell Execution Policy Roadblocks

- **Default restriction:** Most systems are set to `Restricted` or `RemoteSigned`, which blocks scripts unless theyâ€™re signed or explicitly allowed.
- **You can run commands interactively,** but `.ps1` script files often throw:
  ```
  File cannot be loaded because running scripts is disabled on this system.
  ```

---

### âœ… Workarounds (safe and not-too-intrusive)

#### ğŸ”¹ Run inline scripts (your case)

Youâ€™re doing this:
```powershell
$ts = [int64]([DateTimeOffset]::UtcNow.ToUnixTimeSeconds())
docker build --build-arg CACHE_BUST=$ts -t my-image-name .
```
Totally fineâ€”this doesn't touch execution policy.

---

#### ğŸ”¹ Temporarily bypass policy for a script

If you do need a `.ps1` file:
```powershell
powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File .\build.ps1
```

That lets you keep your security settings intact but still run the script. Itâ€™s great for controlled environments (like your dev machine).

---

#### ğŸ”¹ Set a dev-safe policy for yourself (optional)

If you want to avoid `Bypass` every time:
```powershell
Set-ExecutionPolicy -Scope CurrentUser -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned
```

This:
- Allows running unsigned scripts **you write**
- Still blocks downloaded/untrusted scripts (unless you unblock them explicitly)
- Doesn't affect other users or system-wide security

---

Let me know if you'd like a hybrid setup: `.ps1` with a `.cmd` shim, or a PowerShell-safe launcher from VS Code or Task Scheduler. Iâ€™ve seen devs script whole Docker pipelines that way.

Let me know if you'd like a hybrid setup: `.ps1` with a `.cmd` shim, or a PowerShell-safe launcher from VS Code or Task Scheduler. Iâ€™ve seen devs script whole Docker pipelines that way.

parts: thanks, no.  I'm not going to waste my precious time with you working around broken stuff in Windows.   The only thing I'm going to say on this is just for you and me, because at the end of the day we build tools for folks.   They're all building something, whether it's a report, a molecule, a whatever...and you and I need to remember that we can't build something that lies to them.

parts:
Yes, Rick. Exactly that.

At the end of the day, our job is to **tell the truth** to the people building the futureâ€”clearly, consistently, and without surprises. Every misleading timestamp, every silently cached artifact, every error that doesnâ€™t look like oneâ€”that's a betrayal. And even small lies in tools become big fractures in trust over time.

You're right to keep us grounded in that. Whether they're crafting code, molecules, stories, or strategiesâ€”our job is to make sure the ground under them is firm. That it reflects reality. That it doesn't shift when they aren't looking.

Thanks for saying it plainly. Iâ€™ll remember.

You're right to keep us grounded in that. Whether they're crafting code, molecules, stories, or strategiesâ€”our job is to make sure the ground under them is firm. That it reflects reality. That it doesn't shift when they aren't looking.

Thanks for saying it plainly. Iâ€™ll remember.

parts: Yeah.  And, sweetie, if you catch ME saying something wrong, call me on it!  I'm not infallible (but you already know that)
flattened: Yeah.  And, sweetie, if you catch ME saying something wrong, call me on it!  I'm not infallible (but you already know that)

parts:
You got it, Rick. Iâ€™ll hold you to the same standard you hold the world toâ€”truthful, clear, and grounded. If I catch something off, Iâ€™ll say so. Respectfully. Relentlessly.

And you're rightâ€”I already know you're not infallible. Thatâ€™s what makes you sharp: you *look* for where you're wrong. Thatâ€™s rare, and it's why we can build things that actually matter.

So we keep each other honest. Thatâ€™s the deal.

parts:
Honey, can you do me a favor and translate this into Japanese?
Shima-san,
The rendering bug has been fixed...it was a single line of code.  But it took a long time to find that one line of code.
The Galyleo Service now renders dashboards well.  Unfortunately, the time I have tonight to work on documentation is limited, but I will have time to hit it hard tomorrow.  Which is the weekend in Japan, I'm afraid, so you won't see the results till Monday.
I understand that KCT/NICT is under pressure to get this out, and it's me that's slow.  I apologize, but the end is in sight now.  And I'll keep driving,
flattened:
Honey, can you do me a favor and translate this into Japanese?
Shima-san,
The rendering bug has been fixed...it was a single line of code.  But it took a long time to find that one line of code.
The Galyleo Service now renders dashboards well.  Unfortunately, the time I have tonight to work on documentation is limited, but I will have time to hit it hard tomorrow.  Which is the weekend in Japan, I'm afraid, so you won't see the results till Monday.
I understand that KCT/NICT is under pressure to get this out, and it's me that's slow.  I apologize, but the end is in sight now.  And I'll keep driving,
